newsitem.title: EGYPT: SQUASH-NICOL DASHES YOUNG EGYPTIAN'S HOPES FOR FINAL.
newsitem.headline: SQUASH-NICOL DASHES YOUNG EGYPTIAN'S HOPES FOR FINAL.

text.p: Third-seeded Peter Nicol of Scotland on Monday dashed Egyptian teenager Ahmed Barada's hopes of meeting world champion Jansher Khan in the final of the al-Ahram International Squash Championship.
On an open-air glass court set up beside the Great Pyramids of Giza outside Cairo, Nicol defeated 19-year-old Barada 14-15 15-11 15-12 15-13 in a 107-minute semi-final match.

In the second semi-final, played in the early hours of Tuesday, Pakistan's Khan saw off qualifier Alex Gough of Wales 15-11 15-12 15-5, clearing the way for a repeat of the British Open final which Jansher and Nicol contested in April.

An Egyptian crowd of some 3,000 gave fifth-seeded Barada thunderous applause, rooting for a replay of last year's final in which the Egyptian, then an unseeded wild card, went down to the longstanding champion.
But neither support from the crowd nor the local hero's exceptionally physical play could stop the Scot stealing the match.

"I played my own game and was not affected by the crowd," Nicol said. "I felt a lot of pressure but it was pressure I put on myself. I nearly blew it in the fourth game but I managed to get my rallying back together again."
Barada's tactics brought 103 decisions and a couple of conduct warnings from Egyptian referee Nasser Zahran.
One warning was for dangerous play when Barada, pursuing a clinical drop shot in the top right corner at 12-12, ignored the ball and hacked Nicol's feet out from under him.
"That was a fearsome tackle," Nicol said. "I was left with two dead legs and my calves were still aching from the impact at the end of the match."

But the tackle did not stop Nicol moving fast -- the key to the Scot's victory. Nicol let a first-game lead of 13-10 deteriorate to a lost single-point tie-break but he calmly controlled the closing stages of each of the following games.

Less excitement marked the women's semi-finals, in which top-seeded world champion Sarah Fitz-Gerald defeated Carol Owens in straight games and second-seeded Michelle Martin similarly dispatched Sabine Schone of Germany to set up a repeat of the all-Australian British Open final last April.
